wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 7/2/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

9 ways to keep employees motivated during the dog days of summer

With the weather getting warmer and the Fourth of July upon us, it may be difficult for employees to stay focused throughout the workday. In this article, the author shares 9 tips for keeping employees engaged and happy throughout the summer while simultaneously encouraging them to enjoy the benefits of the summer sun. The highlights: unleashing the power of outdoor meetings, letting your employees work remotely, rewarding employees frequently for their hard efforts, and the WeSpire staff favorite, allowing for flexible schedules!

How You Can Use Your Company Health Benefits To Strengthen Employee Engagement

Even with the 2010 Affordable Care Act, employees still remain loyal to the health plans that their companies promote: in a recent survey, 90% reported they would be dissatisfied if their employers dropped their health insurance. What’s more, the data shows that health and wellness programs are good investments for employers to make: 60% of workers with access to a workplace wellness program feel inspired by their company culture to make healthy choices. Employers can tap into that inspiration through promotion of wellness programs at work. Managers can then link the program to direct engagement and business results.

What motivates employees across the globe

The Marcus Buckingham Company recently conducted research surveying the employee engagement climate in various countries across the world, and interestingly, its results show lower engagement levels than those recorded from Gallup’s global study: TMBC showed a 19% full engagement level for the US, whereas Gallup’s global workplace study reported a 29% full engagement level for the US. Out of the eight trends highlighted in the report, the most powerful was the human need to discover strengths and utilize them in the workplace. Read on to find the other seven!

How leaders earn engagement and commitment from employees

All good leaders know that the secret to their success lies within the hard work of their team. Thus, in order to be effective leaders, employers must know how to harness the talents of their team productively. However, the author argues here that we should approach engagement with a different mindset: it is not something to be manipulated and harnessed by managers; instead, engagement is something that must be earned by managers’ respect, compassion, and encouragement.

4 steps to move your company to zero waste

As waste disposal costs have risen by 28% over the past 10 years, more and more companies are looking to save money and boost their corporate sustainability efforts by reducing waste. Zero waste is a lofty business objective that many firms are starting to pursue; yet, they often fall short of the goal because they stop after achieving the quick wins of reduce, reuse, and recycle without optimizing long-term planning. The article outlines four easy steps for companies to embark on their long-term waste objectives. We think step four is the most important: engage employees in better waste diversion.
